They maintain it just so beautifully you can't resist to take a sniff of the crisp old time air. A hint of cigar and old hotel which makes yuo feel so awsome when on a trip. Checking-in is very impressive, from the people who can speak English to Swahili and Japanese to Mandarin it is just impressive to see all of their nametags lined up with what they can speak. It's just awsome to ask them to say everything they just said in their secondary for sheer enjoyment! Travel up the express elevators to your floor to go to the vintage hallways once again to your rooms, which look out into the pool courtyard or one of the many sides of the hotel. I have only had Courtyard view, but it is still a great view! The rooms are old, but new. Comfortable beds, up to date internet and clocks from the next generation! Desks and seating areas are also available. Overall amazing hotel, i'm surprised it's only recieved a 3.5... Definitely stay here if you get a chance!

Reviews.Title: “Very pleasant experience at the Palmer”
Reviews.Author: Travellin_buddy
Reviews.Content: I spent a weekend at the Palmer House Hilton, while visiting Chicago for the first time. Despite being 5 hours early for check in, I was given a room right away. Initially, I was not quite satisfied with my room. There was a constant humming sound (emanating from the elevators) and the view overlooked the side of another very closely situated building so, it gave the room a rather dark, dingy look. I called the front desk to request another room. Since I was still technically early for check-in, I was asked to wait a couple of hours to have a different room assigned to me, which was perfectly understandable. Within an hour, the hotel staff upgraded me to a bigger room with a king bed (at no extra charge) which was situated far away from the elevators and had a much better view of the city. I found the front desk staff to be friendly and quite pleasant to deal with. The concierge staff member was also very friendly and helpful in providing suggestions for dining and places to visit. Overall, I had a very pleasant experience while staying at this hotel, and I would highly recommend it to anyone visiting Chicago.

Reviews.Title: “Good location for short stay”
Reviews.Author: rosentim
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel for two nights in early August and thought it was in a really good location for most of the attractions and it was easy to walk to them. The room was a little on the small side and a bit dated but for a couple of nights was okay. The check in was good and quick and we had no problems. When we requested more towells they were brought to our room within 5 mins. There was evidence of the renovation work which was obvious around the pool area but we never heard any noise from it. Overall I would recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “No Paris no Nicky but still a great stay”
Reviews.Author: hippiekiller
Reviews.Content: The hotel is located in the heart of the theatre district, 10 blocks away from the Sears tower and 3 blocks away from the millenium park. You can easily walk from the hotel to the John Hancock building wich its observatory is voted as the best chicago view. it took me about an hour to get there, i know it sounds like a lot, but its really quite a Nice walk. as of august 2007 trough september The hotel is under maintenance so there were a lot of construction workers, engineers and arquitects working all day long in the hotel facilities. The lobby bar is BEAUTIFUL so having a drink is a must do when you stay at the palmer house. The fitness club is great! really well equiped and it also has a steam room and a sauna. The fitness club service is not free here are all the costs: $ 11 USD 1 day $ 16 USD 2 day $ 21 USD complete stay As for the room: great bed great shower cable TV . Tanno

Reviews.Title: “Just okay”
Reviews.Author: countrygal76
Reviews.Content: My best friend and I took our daughters for a little girls vacation to watch High School Musical on Broadway (which I highly recommend). We took the Amtrak there which I would highly recommend when traveling with children. We arrived at the Palmer House in the late afternoon and we had to wait in line for quite awhile to get checked in. When we finally got to check in, the lady took forever and wasn't friendly at all. She told me that we just had a double bed room and I told her it should be with two bathrooms as well. She agrued with me about it and I told her that I had read reviews on Tripadvisor that they do this to people all the time. I told her that I contacted their hotel directly to book the room and I called to verify our room reservation just the day before and was told that we would have a double bed/2 bath room. She finally went and talked to someone and we got the room we were supposed to but she wasn't friendly about it. I overheard a couple checking in beside me and the same thing was happening to them. I was very disappointed in the check in process. The hotel was beautiful and close to pretty much everything. The restaurant there is wonderful and the Corner Bakery next to it is fabulous. I think the Palmer House is over priced for the service you get but worth it for the location.

Reviews.Title: “So So hotel, not worth the price”
Reviews.Author: PooyaJ
Reviews.Content: The hotel has a beaufitul lobby and facilties but the rooms are antiquated despite the upgrades. I changed rooms and still was not able to escape the loud humming coming from inside Quadrant of the Hotel. For the price, I would stay at the new Hampton Inn down the street.

Reviews.Title: “There are better values in Chicago”
Reviews.Author: TravelingScholar
Reviews.Content: I have stayed at the Palmer House multiple times in the last few years for various conferences. Of the various hotels that I have stayed in while visiting Chicago (I go quite often), I have enjoyed the Palmer House the least. I have never had a truly dreadful experience at the hotel, but I have never truly been made to feel welcome either. When reviewers on this website say the rooms are small, they are not joking. Room size is not something that generally bothers me since I usually travel alone, but I have stayed in rooms that barely had enough space for a full bed and dresser. I will admit that the rooms are generally nicely furnished and that housekeeping does a good (and unobtrusive) job of keeping them clean. I have noticed a change in the attitude of the hotel staff; they have become much more standoffish in the last few years (the previously mentioned housekeeping and doormen/bell desk staff are a laudable exception to this), and they seem to believe that because the hotel has an attractive--though overrated--lobby and is THE Palmer House, you should be grateful that you are allowed to stay. I never feel welcome at the Palmer House, whereas at other hotels in the area that are in the same "peer group," I am always made to feel welcome. However, I must also say that I have never had a real snafu in dealing with the staff either--when I check bags or something like that, everything is properly handled and always ready when I need it. In summary, there is nothing WRONG with this hotel, but I have had more pleasant experiences at similarly priced or less expensive hotels all over the city.

Reviews.Title: “Satisfactory”
Reviews.Author: ArielIreland
Reviews.Content: I stayed in the Palmer House Hilton for 4 nights on business. When I made my reservation I specifically requested a room away from all the banging and drilling, which I didn't get...I was one floor above it. But as I was up early every morning it didn't effect my sleep too much. My room was big and clean, and the cleaning staff did a great job cleaning my room every day. No complaints there. I found the concierge (male) extremely helpful on all times I needed his help. He even recommended a great little nail bar around the corner from the hotel. I had a drink in the lobby one night, the atmosphere was good, but it's very dark and I've been in much nicer places so couldn't really see what all the hype was about! The service wasn't great and I was given my bill before I asked for it. I wasn't happy about that. I'd no issue with checking out. My bill was in order and all I had to do was call a number and I was checked out automatically. If I was going on a holiday I wouldn't stay here, but it was fine for business.

Reviews.Title: “Worst service I have ever experienced at a hotel”
Reviews.Author: Rosebud289
Reviews.Content: Here are my experiences: - Had three rooms reserved, when checked in we were charged 2 different rates for the rooms - screwed up initial room assignments, gave us a room that was not even cleaned yet when we checked in - Could not get us new keys to a different room without great difficulty (we had to go to the front desk because bell staff went to the wrong room to give us new keys) - In room guide says pool in on the 8th floor and signs say it is on the 7th - could not get to the pool from the 14th floor without going all the way down to the lobby and then had to go to the 7th floor and take the stairs to the 8th - When we checked in we had the front desk staff go over which credit cards were assigned to which room. - When we received our bills, the credit card assignments were still wrong. I stay at "economy" hotels a lot and I have not even come close to having this many problems with a hotel until this one. This hotel should do Chicago a service and just close its doors. Due to this experience, I will never stay downtown again to deal with overpriced hotels with poor service and surrounding business that are just as bad.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing stay - there are much better alternatives.”
Reviews.Author: Marcy54
Reviews.Content: My daughter and I stayed at the Palmer House for one night. We were in Chicago to see the sights and attend a play and were sorely dissapointed with the hotel accomodations. While the Palmer House location was great since we were going to the LaSalle Bank Theatre, I'd take a cab to the theatre and stay someplace else next time. The proximity to the Art Instittute and free trolley were nice, but there are other locations close to better shopping, other sites, and more restaurants anyway if you venture up closer to N. Michigan Avenue where the rooms are bigger and the staff friendlier. Our stay started out poorly and never got better. The Hilton Honors receptionist was extremely slow and certainly not welcoming. Because we had read the reviews concerning rennovated vs. non-renovated rooms, we asked specifically for a renovated room when we checked in. We were told that there were none ready yet (although it was after the 3 pm check in time) so we offered to leave our bags with the bellman and come back later. After waiting quite a while without a bellman appearing, we ended up lugging our bags down a level to the storage room ourselves. We returned around 5:30 pm after killing most of the afternoon wandering down State Street, and were given a room. It was renovated, but the SMALLEST two double bed room I have ever seen, and it overlooked a roof with the fire escape right outside our window. Both of us were very dissappointed in the room, and also sorry we had wasted an afternoon of our time in the city waiting to check in, given this was the "upgraded" room we were going to receive. The service matched the rooms. In fact, the only word that comes to mind for the concierge is "snooty". Perhaps it was because we were dressed like tourists in shorts and sandals. (I usually travel for business and treatment of business people seemed to be much better!) While our questions were answered, it was in a very abrupt and non-helpful way and I observed another mother being treated the same. In fact, she was looking for options for her children to ride a boat on the river, and I stopped her afterwards to suggest if they did not want the 90 minute tour she could take them on the water taxi--something the concierge did not even mention--possibly because she did not get any commission on water taxi rides! Several other reviews have suggested this is a great place to go have a drink in the beautiful lobby and see the "old gem" but you'd get better accomodations and superior service at a lower price elsewhere. I'd have to agree. We've stayed at the Embassy Suites on N. State, the Drake (another old gem), the Hilton Garden Inn, the Hyatt and several other hotels near the loop and I'd pick any of them over the Palmer House!

Reviews.Title: “A Little Disappointed, but OK”
Reviews.Author: Shaymus
Reviews.Content: I spent three nights here in early July. The renovations had not started yet so there was no noise. I have to agree that the room was quite small and yes it was dim. It was not bad by any means but I had just arrived from a very nice hotel in Cleveland. I guess I just don't like my one night stopover to be so much nicer than my main event. It's a very historic building, which I like, but very much in need of the renovations that are being done now. The location is excellent, walking distance to Navy Pier, Shedd Aquarium , Sears Tower and the Magnificent Mile. Millineum Park and the Taste of Chicago were right down the street. I would definitely stay here again, but not until after the renovations.

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: jargen
Reviews.Content: An annual conference takes me to Chicago and over the years I have stayed at several hotels near Grant Park and/or Navy Pier. This year was a new experience and I so enjoyed the Palmer House, I will look forward to future conferences even more knowing I can stay there again. The lobby is simply GRAND. DO take some time even if not staying here to walk in, sit down and marvel at the restored frescoed ceiling - touched up by the same artist who restored the Sistine Chapel! The front desk staff was friendly and courteous. The room was spacious and two bathrooms for 3 guests was hard to beat! I appreciated the helpfulness of the concierge staff and on one occasion requested a recommendation for dinner within walking distance. The gentleman's suggestion was such a hit, we went back to thank him after our meal and then returned to the same restaurant for another meal later in our stay. The ONLY complaint I have about this hotel was that our key cards (7 keys total for 3 guests over 3 days) NEVER worked properly. On arrival, we could not enter the room with ANY key and had to return to the front desk for new keys. One guest's keys never worked the whole time we stayed. On another occasion we couldn't get any key to work, went back to the front desk and advised that we were having such a hard time. The response of the staff at that point was disappointing, something like, "Yeah, we know there's a problem." That's all, they knew there was a problem. Not, "We're trying to fix it" or "We'll send maintenance up to change out your door lock" or even "We apoligize for any inconvenience". That could have been handled better ESPECIALLY when they know there's a problem and it was obvious we came all the way back to the front desk from the 18th floor to be able to get into our room! I would have rated them 5 stars if it hadn't been for this indifference to the inconvenience of their guests. That aside, as I said, I will look forward to staying here again. The location is wonderful - Starbucks, Corner Bakery Cafe, pharmacies and the like all on the same block; numerous restaurants within walking distance; the Art Institute nearby as well as the symphony. As their current renovation gets completed, this will be SO worth the price to be in the heart of Chicago at a truly beautiful luxurious hotel.

Reviews.Title: “We liked it! Surprised at the number of bad reviews”
Reviews.Author: CincyFamily
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed here for three nights last week. We really enjoyed it. I'm surprised at the bad reviews. Yes, it is true that some parts of the hotel are under renovation, but I never came across those areas. Please don't get the impression that you will be dodging construction areas throughout. I never saw them. The main lobby of the hotel is beautiful, and always very active. There is a lounge there that is usually very active in the afternoon and evening. We are Hilton Honors members, and they have a separate check-in area just for us, which was nice. We also had access to the Executive lounge, which was a very nice and unexpected perk. Free breakfast, and free snack and soft drinks throughtout the day. It was a nice little get-away. The rooms are on the small side, but I'm not sure what others were expecting in an older hotel. The bathroom was perfectly fine, certainly not what I would call small. Normally, we stay at a hotel near the northern end of Michigan Ave., but we decided to try someting different this time. We really liked being close to the museums and Millenium Park.

Reviews.Title: “Average Hotel”
Reviews.Author: AllyL
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 5 nights this month and although the service was OK it is nothing to rave about. The Lobby is very grand but the rooms are very small and housekeeping was not very reliable and even although the room was cleaned coffee tea not replenished. The situation of the hotel is great just a short walk to Millenium Park, Art Institute etc. Don't have breakfast in the hotel as very pricey, go to the Corner Bakery jut outside hotel.

Reviews.Title: “beware first impressions”
Reviews.Author: brocakc
Reviews.Content: The foyer was fabulous but it ended there. The rooms were average, there was never an adequate internet signal despite advertising this as a free service. Booked twin beds and given a king and told that since this was how it was booked( through a travel service), it could not be changed?! Finally, we returned to our room to find the door propped open by housekeeping with no one in sight anywhere on the entire floor, no one returning after ten minutes, the room half cleaned and despite a call downstairs, a manager never appeared nor called to address our security concern. To add insult , the room was never cleaned nor were supplies replenished!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Stay at Palmer House Hilton”
Reviews.Author: scruffygirl
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Palmer House on a trip to Chicago last December for an international band and orchestra convention. It was my first time to Chicago and from the moment I arrived at the hotel, it was a great experience. Upon walking in we were greeted with, "Good afternoon, welcome to the Palmer House, we've been expecting you!" I thought that was a neat way to greet guests. The room was ready for us early, and exactly as booked. The decor was much more tasteful than what I usually encounter in hotels and the bed was extremely comfortable. The room and bathroom were on the large side and everything was very well cleaned and maintained. Yes, you can hear the 'el' trains even on some upper floors, but it's just a low rumble that I found helped me go to sleep! There is a Corner Bakery downstairs as well as a CVS across the street. The concierge recommended Giordano's for some great Chicago style pizza and it was wonderful. The location was great for the convention, and convenient to trains and dining and very close to milennium park. Keep in mind, I did get a relatively low rate since I was with the convention, so that's why I feel like it was a good value. (Paid less than half what is normally advertised on their website.)

Reviews.Title: “Extremely average & overpriced”
Reviews.Author: AdiMD
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Palmer House Hilton for 3 nights in January 2007 as part of a 2 week holiday also visiting NY, Dallas & Vegas. The best feature of the Palmer House is the foyer which, as you can see from any photos used for advertising, is extremely grand. This gives, I feel, an inaccurate picture of what you expect the rest of the hotel to be like - 5 star, but that it ain't! It's not that its dirty or the staff are rude but the rooms are average & the decor is too & the staff service is OK but in no way, shape or form do they go above & beyond for you. I also had to pay an extra fee to use the gym facilities. Pretty much a standard hotel & service but charged out as if it were luxury. We won't be staying here again as I'm sure there are many other Chicago hotels that offer better value for money.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointed”
Reviews.Author: hunter2000
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Plamer House one night last week and I came away greatly disappointed. As a diamond member I was originally denied access to the executive lounge. It took a number of phone calls and finally a visit down to the front desk to resolve. They tried to claim that I had to pay to access the lounge. Unreal. Aside from that issue, the standard room was quaint, but clean. However it did have issues as well. 1. The drain for the tub was not installed. Basically an open hole in the tub served that purpose. 2. The lock on the bathroom door was not functional. 3. The phones (both of them) could not access the message function and would cut out. I'm guessing these physical issues with the property will be resolved with the renovation currently under way. Ended up at the Drake the following night and it was everything the Palmer House was not.

Reviews.Title: “Could be better with some common sense”
Reviews.Author: angusyoungrocks
Reviews.Content: Rooms are small but very clean. Pool closed on one day, yet hotel still wanted to charge patrons $11 to work out in exercise room. Common sense would dictate the hotel pick up the cost to work out in exercise room. Brought this up to hotel staff and they said hotel and exercise room are owned by two disparate companies, thus unable to waive cost. Still, that doesn't preclude the hotel from picking up the tab for exercise room when they close the pool, without notice, for repairs. In all, people are generally very friendly and hospitable. There was, however, a bit too much construction going on in the a.m. Daughter was trying to sleep at 8 a.m. and was awakened by the sound of hammering from above (we were at one of the top floors). If I had it all to do over again, I'd pay the extra $$ and stay on the north side of the river.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location for Fireworks”
Reviews.Author: profpat
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed overnight at the Palmer House on July 3, 2007 to be downtown for the 4th of July fireworks. LOCATION This hotel is in a terrific location for the fireworks. You are two blocks away from the Taste of Chicago and the Petrillo Band shelter. If you go one more block east, you walk thru Buckingham Fountain and are right at the Lake. The fireworks are set off from a barge on the lake, and this is the perfect location to see them. SECURITY There was a virtual â€œseaâ€� of people flooding the streets after the fireworks. We walked in the crowd and got to the front of our hotel. There were at least 10 security guards outside the hotel, asking to see your room key before they would let you in. I thought that was great. When we left our room initially to go to the fireworks, we saw a security guard patrolling the halls on our floor. He spoke to us and said the hotel was a full capacity and all the security staff were working that evening. This hotel really had their act together. LOBBY AREA The common area of the lobby features a gorgeous bar and many comfortable, elegant high-back gold velvet chairs scattered throughout. There are comfy sofas, cute end tables and coffee tables too. The tables had a beautiful vase with glass marbles, water and lit candles floating amidst fresh, fragrant flowers. The lobby smelled heavenly as a result of the floral displays and the candle dÃ©cor really added a nice touch. My husband and I had a drink there around 7pm, before we went down to see the fireworks. As soon as you sit down, a waiter gets your drink order and gives you a snack mix (chex mix kind of thing) to accompany your drink. Just sitting there gazing at all the frescos, paintings and elaborate moldings in this historic room is worth staying at this hotel. It was lovely. SWIMMING POOL We did not go swimming due to time constraints, but we did go to the 8th floor to see it. The pool is rectangular and small. (This is NOT an Olympic size pool or anythingâ€¦I would estimate that it is less than one half the size of an Olympic size pool.) There were chairs scattered around so you could sit and watch the people swim while you read or something. The ceiling is really high and glass (like a greenhouse) which would let in lots of light. There were parents with kids swimming while we checked it out at approximately 7pm on Tuesday night. ROOM We were on the 18th floor. When the elevator doors open, there are pretty chairs and floral arrangements in the lobby area that look really nice. We got to our room and found it to be adequate. (After all, we were just sleeping there.) The building is really old and as a result, the ceilings are kind of low. (Around 7 feet, I would sayâ€¦) For example, I could literally reach up and touch the ceiling fixtures in the halls and Iâ€™m only 5 feet 1. Our room was a little on the small side, and seemed smaller due to the low ceiling. The bathroom was really super-tiny. My husband kept bumping his arm into the walls in there as the tried to brush his teeth at night. But, it was clean and well-decorated. The soaps and shampoo stuff was Crabtree and Evelyn and smelled divine. The room had a coffeemaker in it. PRICE I booked the hotel directly on the Hilton website for $179.00. They add a room tax later which brings the bill up to a little over $200. I felt that was reasonable, given the great location during a holiday. PARKING We live in the suburbs and drove into the city. We used the Hiltonâ€™s valet service and let them park our car. That was $38. It was kind of pricey but we were willing to pay for the convenience. We wanted to simply drop off the car, check in to the hotel and then wander around. So it worked out well for us. Plus, when we checked out the next day, they got us our car in a matter of a few minutes. That was great. I saw a self-park high-rise garage right next to the hotel, but during crowded holidays I donâ€™t know how that would be. (I think the sea of people after the fireworks would have kept you from pulling out for hours and hours. And the frustration of trying to â€œfind a spotâ€� in the garage in the first place, seems like it would be a pain to me.) OVERALL This is a nice hotel with a historic â€œfeelâ€� to it. The location was great for our purposes and all the staff we dealt with (check-in, security, bar, valet etc) were professional, polite and friendly even though it was obviously a busy evening for them. The hotel was well-staffed to cover the added traffic. We would stay here again. If you have any questions, my email is: pborowia@netscape.net.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent”
Reviews.Author: Solange72
Reviews.Content: Overall excellent stay at the Hilton Palmer House this weekend. Pros: good prices on the hotel website with AAA rates, Extremely beautiful lobby with breathtaking ceiling, comfortable spacious rooms (a few signs of wear are excpected in old houses and old hotels), nice coffee and toiletries, good room service with reasonable prices for kid menu, nice swimming pool (for Chicago), excellent fitness center (free to elite hilton members, otherwise you have to pay a daily fee), multiple elevators, no congestion, no noise from other rooms (or renovation?), easy parking (if expensive as is normal for downtow chicago). Cons: check in a tiny little bit slow but only because the front desk was giving much information to people in front of the line. In conclusion, you stay at an architectural and historical landmark.

Reviews.Title: “Anniversary Weekend”
Reviews.Author: angel037
Reviews.Content: My husband and I came to celebrate our one year anniversary. We got a great price through Hotwire. The outside of the hotel and the lobby are beautiful. The room, however, was much smaller than I thought it would be. Renovations are being completed, so I hope the rooms will be updated. It was very quiet for us. Our room was on the 21st floor, and they are currently working on the 14th floor. They were a little slow to check us in. After working all day, catching a flight and arriving at 9pm, we just wanted to go to our room. Everyone was really friendly. The hotel was very close to the Taste of Chicago that is going on this week, and 2 blocks from Michigan Avenue.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect....If through Priceline”
Reviews.Author: CSwan
Reviews.Content: This is the ideal hotel if you book it through Priceline, Hotwire or one of the other discount booking sites. You'll get it for alot less than booking through the hotel directly, which will cause you to be a little more tolerant of dated decor, small rooms and the constant noises coming from the on-going remodeling of the hotel. The Palmer House is ideally located just south of the river and just inside the Loop very close to the El and blue and red metro lines. You're close to all the shopping and major attractions Chicago has to offer. The decor of this hotel has a definite 80's, floral patterned, faux-renaissance look to it. In this day and age of hip, boutique hotels with neutral colors and sleek lines, the Palmer House is a fossil. When I mentioned small rooms, I must admit, I was fortunate enough to get a room on the 17th floor that at an earlier time had been two rooms (I viewed a few rooms being cleaned, and the bed took up ALOT of space). It was simple to tell my room had been two separate rooms because it was easy to determine where the extra wall had once been and there were two, identical bathrooms on either side of the room. You may luck out and get a room that is not near the current area of remodeling, but just in case bring earplugs. I was awakened at 6 a.m. on a Friday by the drilling and banging. After calling down to the front desk, I was informed that that was the hour working began during the week. Weekends (yes, Sunday too) aren't much better; they get started at 7 a.m. All in all, it was worth the money spent (thanks to Priceline). If you are looking for a clean, centrally located hotel in a great city, then this is it.

Reviews.Title: “Solid hotel... looking forward to seeing the renovations!”
Reviews.Author: ChaunceyGardiner
Reviews.Content: Quick one night stay here, less than 24 hours in-house. Check-in at HHonors desk was quick, freebie Palmer House brownie was a nice touch. I asked (based on prior postings here) for a corner room, and was offered one, but it would have been a wait for it to be cleaned, so I took the room he gave me. All staff uniformly helpful and smiling. Not a renovated room, although very, very niceâ€¦ fully a 4star room. Comfy bed with nice linens; bathroom was sparkling, and the Crabtree & Evelyn stuff was nice. High speed internet was hardwired in the rooms, and connection was solid. Major renovations, inside and out, are clearly in progress. No noise detectable in the evenings, although they do start promptly at 8am. Should be pretty spectacular when they are done. The main lobby has a temporary bar, but Iâ€™d be happy to come back in a few months and see how things turn out. One minor, minor complaint: there is no Cingular/at&t cell or Blackberry coverage in the lobbyâ€¦ you must go out to the street to transmit or carry on a phone call. Only one restaurant was open (the Big Downtown) and it was fineâ€¦ actually had an $18 ribeye- WOWâ€¦ havenâ€™t seen one of those in a Hilton lately! Service was efficient and friendly. No hotel coffee available at 5:00am, but there is a Starbucks and a Dunkin Donuts within a blockâ€™s walk, so no problem. Free airline check-in kiosk with printer, so thatâ€™s nice. Location is excellent, taxi queue was full and available. Would happily stay here againâ€¦ especially to see how the renovations turn out on this Grande Dame hotelâ€¦ Iâ€™d like to see it (when finished) next to the Palace in San Francisco and the Willard in Washington! Check-out was smooth; bellstand helpful with a bag while I went to meetings.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Palmer House”
Reviews.Author: ehs444
Reviews.Content: Excellent stay in the Towers' Executive level with private concierge floor featuring breakfast and evening snacks. Lovely and comfortable room. Lobby is a must see. Friendly and helpful staff. Hotel is undergoing a restoration, but it did not hinder our stay. Superb location, minutes from Michigan Ave, Art Institute, Millenium and Grant Parks, the "EL" train and the best of what we wanted to see and do in Chicago. We are looking forward to returning when renovation of this 1871 landmark historical hotel is complete, shoud be a sight to see.

Reviews.Title: “Great Family Stay”
Reviews.Author: gherman
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a week in Chicago with the family. This hotel was perfect for us. Location is great, kids loved the pool as a place to wind down after a day of museums, touring, ball games, etc. We checked in through Hilton Honors Desk as opposed to the regular check in line. Even though our reservations were through priceline at a reduced rate, they gave us a pick of the the rooms. The room had a large closet which helped with the amount of gear we had with us. Used valet parking which was hasselfree. We had a great experience and would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “History being redone”
Reviews.Author: miatraveler
Reviews.Content: This is a beautiful old historic hotel in the midst of a total renovation. All of the rooms, hallways and furnishings are being redone, so it would not be prudent to review here at this point. The service however is a standout and can be reviewed. Desk staff is courteous and accommodating, housekeeping did an excellent job, room service was exceptionally fast, concierges are helpful and appear to be hotel employees, not farmed out by a tourist company trying to sell you their products. with such great service, after renovations are complete, this will truly be a phenomenal hotel!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Elegant business hotel at central location”
Reviews.Author: fkaway
Reviews.Content: This historic hotel is situated at a central location, just 1 block away from Michigan Avenue and approx. 15mins. walk from â€œThe Magnificent Mileâ€œ, where youâ€™ll find lots of restaurants and of course shopping opportunities. Itâ€™s a business hotel with a convention center. Even within proximity youâ€™ll find lot of restaurants&stores. The next hop on/hop off city bus stop is just 2 blocks away, not more than 5mins walk. Our opulent room for 2 nights at the 20th floor had twin beds and 2 separate but small bathrooms and 2 wardrobes, view goes into the quiet building backyard. Internet is extra, WIFI is not available in the rooms nor a Inroom safe. A safe at no charge is available at the front desk. Thereâ€™s a Iron board. Thanks to my Hilton Gold-card we had access to the business lounge, where they offer continental breakfast buffet until 10am as well as Hors dâ€™oeuvre starting at 4pm. This hotel has a real great fitness center with a large pool. Valet parking is available for $38.- p.day, self parking for $30.- Service is outstanding in this hotel.

Reviews.AuthorLocation: Great Wolf Lodge Traverse City, MI
Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel, but a few minor issues...”
Reviews.Author: thelazyk
Reviews.Content: I am a HH Gold member and booked this as a reward stay. We had GREAT service and a fast easy check in process. We were given a large CORNER room (view on all 3 sides!) which had two full size beds (NOT queens as we requested). The biggest drawback was that the EL was outside of our room and did not make for a very quiet night or restful sleep (even with earplugs!). We opted to "self park" in the neighboring parking garage, and had a few problems with our ticket coming up as invalid during trips in and out of the garage. The HH desk staff fixed the parking problem immediately, which was a great help. Every staff person we encountered was incredibly nice and helpful and the hotel itself was very clean. The building IS old, so expect to see some cracks and "character" throughout, but it is a great reminder of the fascinating history of this building. Whatever you do...DON'T miss out on trying an original Palmer House brownie! You can get them "to go" from The Big Downtown restaurant right on the street level of the hotel. They are AMAZING!

Reviews.Title: “Very comfortable stay”
Reviews.Author: mmissner
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Palmer House for one night in early May. We were in Chicago to see the Cezanne to Picasso exhibit at the Art Institute so the hotel was almost on the museum steps.. We got the hotel on Hotwire. We are Hilton Gold Card holders so check in was a breeze. Some Hilton hotels will give you concierge floor rooms even if you booked through a discounter, but the Palmer House did not. We had a very nice corner, quiet room on a high floor and had a very pleasant stay. It is a great location for the museum, Millenium Park, Concert hall, and more..

Reviews.Title: “Great Location, Unremarkable Experience”
Reviews.Author: JAtlanta
Reviews.Content: This hotel's selling points are its lovely lobby, great location, and customer service. My thoughts: I'd booked a room at the hotel's Looptopia special, which was just $99 a night, which just assured me one double bed. On arrival, I requested an upgrade and was upgraded free of charge to a room with two double beds, two closets, and two bathrooms. The room was clearly a combination of what had been two separate rooms and, though oddly laid out, was quite roomy. The bathrooms were very clean and modern enough for an old hotel. It was not as nice as what I'm used to in the US (it would be great by European standards) but it was acceptable. From the hotel's online pictures I'd expected that the rooms would have been remodeled. There weren't. The beds were older but fairly comfortable, and had duvets and nice linens. The tv, phones, curtains, chairs, furnishings, and carpet, though, were very dated. We were on the 20th floor, so no problems with street noise. Only noise from neighbors was running water and flushing toilets, which were easily heard in our room. I felt a bit nickel and dimed, though, as the hotel didn't have a really business center and charged for internet access in its two public computers. Most hotels offer this free. Also, the key card wallet contained a notice that they include a USA Today in the cost of the room and if we didn't want the paper we could call the front desk to cancel it and have the bill reduced by 75 cents a day. We did not cancel the paper, but did not receive it either. We were charged for the paper. Finally, not having a mini bar was annoying. The fridge was locked with a note that food and beverages were available through room service only. The bottled water in the room was 3.95, which is far more than other hotels. The concierge was quite helpful and always on duty, and the front desk staff were very polite. The lobby, even under construction, is just beautiful and if the lobby restrooms are a reflection of the remodeling efforts the remodeled hotel will be lovely.

Reviews.Title: “I'll take my history at a museum, please.”
Reviews.Author: DCBuffalo
Reviews.Content: Traveled to Chicago for two nights on business, and arrived at the Palmer House around 10pm. HHonors Desk was closed, but was checked in quickly nonetheless. This hotel boasts that it is the oldest continuously operating hotel in the country. The first room I was checked into must have been the oldest continuously operating room in the hotel! It looked like it hadn't been renovated in about 20 years (the green tile in the bathroom was quite charming... really.) and had a lovely view of an A/C compressor that was bigger than my room! Went back to the reception desk, and asked if an HH Gold upgrade to the exec floor upgrade was available. Was upgraded to exec floor, to a room with one double bed. Room was nicer than the last one, but you couldn't have parked a Yugo in there with enough room to open the doors! Stay was pleasant enough afterwards. A bit noisy during the night. Lobby is undergoing renovations. Exec lounge was fine. Not bad for a business trip, but next time I'll be staying somewhere that has a bit less "history" in my room!

Reviews.Title: “Cannot Make It..”
Reviews.Author: Zin2
Reviews.Content: Stayed recently for a conference and paid US199 per nite. I had requested beforehand for, and was assured at reception upon check-in that my room was one of the newer, upgraded ones. But turned out to be an old room. As it was already past midnite, I didn't bother to complain. I shall not repeat the other reviewers' comments about the smallness of the room and toilet, shocking lack of room fridge (for a purportedly premier property) ) and general tiredness of the property. If I do return to Chicago, which is a great city, I really see no compelling reason to stay in the Palmer again.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay on the Towers level”
Reviews.Author: jpl88
Reviews.Content: After reading the reviews here on Tripadvisor I was a little worried about the quality of the property. I booked one of the two beds 2 bathroom rooms on the Towers level and am pleased to report that we had a wonderful stay. The room was large with two smallish double beds, a sofa bed facing a coffee table and 32" TV and DVD player. There was also space for a work desk, extra chairs and table with coffee maker. The two windows faced other rooms and there wasn't much of a view. Because we were on the last floor there was a good amount of natural light. It looked like the room was renovated recently, it was nicely decorated and had an upscale feel to it. The two bathrooms were on the small side, however we preferred having two small bathrooms than one large one. The towers lounge served breakfast, hors d'oeuvres and snacks and drinks throughout the day. The breakfast was a little light but hors d'oeuvres were satisfactory. One other advantage of the towers lounge is the private elevators that take you directly to the towers levels from the lobby. We never had to wait long for an elevator. On the 23rd floor there was no noise or disturbances from the renovations. The location of the hotel is fantastic with easy access to the blue line to and from the airport and many other lines. Also very close walking distance to the Art Institute. There are a few restaurants around, coffee shops and convenience stores as well. One disappointment was the fee assessed for every package I had delivered to the hotel. Most hotels usually keep them at the front desk which is easier and free. Here you have to go to a UPS store on a different level and they will charge you $5 for each item. Other than this I have nothing bad to say about our stay. It was nice to stay in a property with more character and history than the usual Hilton. Judging from the other reviews, you obviously have to make sure you get the right type of room if you want to have a good experience at this property. This is an old hotel so rooms have different sizes and some are not renovated. However my review is based on my experience and I would recommend the 2 bathroom tower level rooms. Property: 4/5 Service: 4/5 Room: 5/5 Amenities: 5/5 Views: 2/5 Location: 5/5 Cleanliness: 5/5 My rating: 4/5

Reviews.Title: “Hilton Honors member loves it”
Reviews.Author: squirrelgardens
Reviews.Content: Grand dame is the only word. If you are traveling to use your Hiltons Honors.....there is a separate check in desk near the escalators. I got a had written thank you note from the HH desk in the evening under my door. Nice touch. Business center and fitness club use is not complimentary. Hotel is going under a major refit...so one restaurant. The food was very good with better service. My room was on the smallish side but clean and quiet. They placed me in an area that they deemed for the female solo travelers. Chicago has some petty crime in the loop and I appreciated this attention. Will return. Place my luggage with the Bell Captain and walked one block to the Art Institute for one hour. Elegant hotel with Old World Service.

Reviews.Title: “room/bathroom way too small”
Reviews.Author: rodrig
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Palmer House on business. I was so disapointed in the size of the room and bathroom. I had a small cosmetic bag and there was litterally no counter space in the bathroom, only a small ledge above the toilet where my things kept falling into. I was not too impressed by the check-in service although a particular bell hop was especially helpful. The concierge was medicore. I am going back on business in May and I am going to try staying somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “Loved The Palmer House”
Reviews.Author: Alvin&Tracy
Reviews.Content: My wife booked this trip as a surprise for my 30th birthday, we spent five nights in the windy city and loved every minute of it. The Palmer House is in a great location, with a great bar Millers, right next to it we loved the old style wooden booths in this bar. It snowed while we were there, which made it a bit more special for us. We ice skated in Millennium park, walked to the aquarium which has great views of the city, walked around soldier field in the snow. Visited Lincoln park and the zoo. The Sears towers are a must. And cocktails at The Drake!, There is a great little diner right outside the Palmer House, we ate breakfast there every day. We even managed to get to see The Jerry Springer Show, what a laugh!! I would recommend The Palmer House for anyone who likes historic hotels, maybe not for those who enjoy the more modern Contemporary type.

Reviews.Title: “It's okay., for my Grandparents.”
Reviews.Author: cooper12
Reviews.Content: Stayed there last week for a business meeting. The staff from the start was horrible. I was told because they were so busy that I would have to wait for a room. I asked for the manager and while waiting for her two others in my party were given room keys. The manager said she was sorry and all of a sudden a room was available. Not sure what the problems is there. The room was small and old. The lobby, meeting, and ballrooms were incredible. The construction was minor. If I were wanting to relive the Roaring 20's or searching for Al Capone's loot this is the place. Otherwise there are a lot of great hotels in Chicago. This is not one of them.

Reviews.Title: “Overall good experience”
Reviews.Author: JCNL
Reviews.Content: I had read numerous reviews about this property, and had originally been disappointed at winning this bid via priceline. We had been worried we'd get a forced into a one bed small room, which would have been a problem as we required 2 separate beds. We were also bummed out to find out the hotel was under renovations as one of the good things we heard about the hotel was its lobby. However, it was a final thing since it was priceline. We walked into the hotel and thought the lobby was indeed worth the hype. There was a small section that had been closed off due to renovations, but it didn't not detract much from the beauty. The check-in was painless, but there weren't many people at that hour. We got a pretty big room. 2 queen? sized beds, 2 comfy chairs, ottoman, tv, minibar, desk. The furnishings did look a bit worn, but it was clean and the beds were comfy. The bathroom also was indeed a bit small, but it was good enough. We had no view really, but we weren't expecting any to begin with. We did hear the train, but it's Chicago...we did not hear any renovations at any time, but I must admit we were hardly in the room in the day. The gap between the floor and the door is also indeed huge, I can see why people said it was loud. It let in a lot of light, but even tho we were at a T-intersection of the hallways, we never heard anything. I also barely heard our neighbours to either side. The location is fantastic as many others have said, close to trains, bus to museum campus, Miller's pub right downstairs for late night food (most other things are closed), and the Corner Bakery served a pretty good breakfast. It's also a block away from the park and the park parking lot (which is a lot cheaper than Palmer house parking). The only complaint I would have is after extending our stay (again via priceline), we asked them two times if it would be ok, and if we would have to check out and recheck in. We were told both times that we were fine. But lo and behold, when we got back the next day, our keys didn't work and we did end up having to go down to get them recoded. Minor inconvenience, but the receptionist was pretty snobby/rude when I asked her why we had to do this when we were told we didn't have to. I would definately not mind staying here again.

Reviews.Title: “Great atmosphere”
Reviews.Author: dfbblue
Reviews.Content: Location, location, location.....Stayed in Palmer House Hilton for 4 nights from 21st March. We had a Kingsize room. Spotlessly clean and very spacious. Its an old style hotel but very elegant. The bed was soooooooo comfy. We had read so many mixed review that we were a bit anxious about staying there but we have to say we had a great stay at the hotel and would definitely go back again. They are in the middle of renovating but we could not tell. Staff very friendly and efficient.

Reviews.Title: “It is Good to be Gold”
Reviews.Author: AThena53
Reviews.Content: My husband and I have Gold status with Hilton and the Palmer House has been nice to me over the years. This trip was no exception. I walked past the hordes checking and and found the HHonors Desk, where I was immediately given an upgraded room on the Executive Floor. It was a corner room with a beautiful view of the Lake, and the room had been recently renovated. I was a bit surprised to find a well-dressed gentleman packing his bags as I walked in- he said he was an executive at the Palmer House and was just leaving. No problem- the room looked completely undisturbed. Executive Floor goodies in the evening werenâ€™t too bad- a cash bar, but the food included empanadas, veggie spring rolls, a very nice assortment of cheeses, and fresh fruit. There was also a case of complimentary soft drinks, water and juices. Not much of a view, but extensive seating, a large TV and plenty to read, along with an employee who helped with check-in and check-out. I got back to my room after a dip in the pool (smallish, typical of city hotels, over-warmed, over-chlorinated) and found a complimentary bottle of wine with a note- apparently from the guy whoâ€™d been in the room! Very nice touch, and it was good wine. Health Club (fee for use by non-HHonors members) had a lot of new-looking equipment. Cable Internet was reliable and was $12/day- not bad compared to Hiltonâ€™s properties in Europe. It would be even better if it were included in the room rate, of course. Executive Lounge breakfast the next morning was pretty much standard continental breakfast fare. A few minuses: my room did not have a bathtub, but it did have a shower with two nozzles that were adjustable for height and angle- so if youâ€™re tall it doesnâ€™t hit you in the chest. The Executive Floor had an Express elevator, which did not go to the Health Club Floor so I had to take it one floor below and wander around in my swimsuit and T-shirt and find the elevator that got me to where I wanted to go. The rooms were not well-soundproofed; I could hear the muffled sound of the TV next door. I was glad I wasnâ€™t next to party animals. I could also hear the El (the elevated subway train) rumble by even from the 23rd floor. Not surprising- this is Chicago- but you might want to bring ear plugs if this would bother you. All in all, a nice stay. Hilton really tries to take care of its Elite members. The airlines could learn from them.

Reviews.Title: “Ongoing work spoilt stay”
Reviews.Author: gandvuk
Reviews.Content: Whatever plus points there might be about this hotel, they count for nothing when ongoing renovation at the hotel means that during our stay - and over the weekend - workman at times carried on drilling until 9.00pm and then started again at 6.00am with the noise reverberating loudly up to our 13th floor. To be fair, the manager did give us a $75.00 voucher to spend in the hotel on the night we complained at 9.00pm about the noise. However when the drilling commenced at 6.00am - yes 6.00 on a Saturday morning! - it seems they hadn't taken on board our concerns but simply tried to pay us off. When I asked to be moved I was told they were very sorry and I would be contacted later by the duty manager. I didn't hear from anyone after that. Don't stay until they've finished renovating!

Reviews.Title: “Bit disappointing”
Reviews.Author: creamslacks
Reviews.Content: Booked the hotel for a business stay and was disappointed. Very grand from the outside but the rooms were really quite dated and small. Mine was a standard room but one of the smallest rooms i've experienced at a Hilton. Very dated also. The internet sockets were hanging of the wall and it smelt musty. The hotel is undergoing renovations so when you book ask for a renovated room. Ok but not if your paying full rates.

Reviews.Title: “Over-rated and far better hotels to stay at”
Reviews.Author: nurse1898
Reviews.Content: Have just returned from Chicago where I stayed at the Palmer Hilton for business. Whilst situated in down town chicago, with a five min access to to Lake Michagin and near shops etc, I wouldn't recommend staying here. The entrance is fabulous and the internal lobby spectacular but that is where it stops. The rooms whilst kept clean are small, pokey and very dated in terms of decor. The desk staff surly and unhelpful. We were a group of about 30 and there were numerous -- with the rooms, some of us ended up sleeping on couches in the lounge as they had rebooked our rooms out on our first night. Billing was a problem and most had numerous issues with internet access. No real view from the rooms. At the latter part of our stay some of us moved and you can get get far better hotels with a lake view rooms and modern clean decor at a far cheaper price. In addition at what 4-5 star hotel do you have you pay for the gym or pool. Wouldn't stay here again and the other 29 would also agree.

Reviews.Title: “Longterm Palmer House customer finally writing a review...”
Reviews.Author: velevele
Reviews.Content: After having stayed at the Palmer House more than 50 times over the last several years (both for work and personal stays), I thought it was time to finally express an opinion about it! I'm now a diamond Hilton Honors member, but started my stays here as a lowly blue. I feel at this point I've experienced pretty much everything the Palmer has to offer, and this review will reflect my years of experience with this hotel. (I apologize in advance for the length!) The Palmer is a classic old hotel, with a lot of variability, and your experience here will depend on a number of things: -- How full it is. The hotel is VERY popular with tour groups. If you are checking in at a time a tour group is arriving, you may find the lobby very crowded. (The lobby is presently undergoing renovation, and the roomy, spacious seating areas have been, at least temporarily, eliminated.) -- What room you have (size). The Palmer has some of the smallest (US) hotel rooms I've ever seen (usually called "studio" rooms on their website), but it also has some of the largest. I've stayed in everything from a studio room where the bed pretty much occupied the entire room to suites that were bigger than some apartments I've lived in (one suite I've had a couple of times must be close to 1000 sq ft). My advice: inquire about room size when you book your room. The size of the bed is not necessarily correlated with the room size. A room with one double bed can be larger than a room with a king or larger than a room with two double beds. On the other hand, studio rooms can be good bargains if you don't mind having essentially no free floor space. -- What room you have (view). Many rooms at the Palmer have "views" over building infrastructure or what seems like directly into other rooms. If you want to avoid this, ask for a room that faces directly (not obliquely) onto Adams or Monroe. Nowhere in the Palmer has "great" views, but streetside views will at least let you see some skyline. -- Your Hilton Honors level, if any. I've always been treated courteously at Palmer House, even before I joined the Hilton Honors program, but diamond members do get better treatment and additional amenities. Now on to some specifics: -- Executive floor. Honors members have access to this, but it can be hard to get a room on this floor (it's the 23rd floor). If you want the executive floor specifically and not just access, be sure to request the 23rd floor. Breakfast is served (fruit, yogurt, donuts, muffins, bagels, juice, cereal, etc. -- no hot items other than what you stick in the toaster), as well as hot hors d'oeuvres in the evening, and cookies and snacks at night. Soft drinks, juice, bottled water, and coffee/tea are available for free any time the kitchen area is open (typically around 6.30 AM till 11 PM). If you're staying on floors 21 or 22, it's usually quicker to access the 23rd floor via the stairs (bring your key; you will need it to get out of the stairs on the 23rd floor) than the elevator. -- Fitness center. Open nice and early on weekdays (5.30 AM), and fairly large, although it can get crowded during weekdays, when there are a lot of business travelers. I've found weekend mornings to be far less crowded. If you're not at least a Hilton Gold (I think Gold and not Silver, but don't quote me on that) member, there's a charge. Theoretically, there's a 25-minute limit on equipment when other people are waiting, a policy I don't agree with. -- Elevators. There are three banks of elevators at Palmer House (plus a semi-hidden "executive elevator" set), and they go to three separate sets of floors. You can transfer between all elevator banks on the 8th floor, which is often easier and faster than transferring at the lobby or street level. If the hotel is very full, or if one or more elevators are down for repairs, you can have quite a long wait for elevators. The executive elevators are accessed from just across from the concierge's desk, but they only go to a limited number of floors and require an executive-access key card. -- Rooms (continued). The Palmer House is undergoing an extensive renovation, and some floors are closed. Also, the beds and amenities are being replaced piecemeal rather than all at once, since the hotel is remaining open during renovations. Some rooms have the new beds and amenities, and others don't. Ask at the time of your reservation if this is important to you. Standard amenities include shampoo, conditioner, lotion, and mouthwash; upgraded rooms often have robes and fluffy bathroom rugs that the other rooms don't have. I'm not sure if Palmer eventually plans to put all amenities in all rooms. -- Staff. I've never been treated anything other than courteously at Palmer House, but competence of staff has varied. Twice (in over 50 stays) I've been charged for minibar items I didn't take (both times I was credited promptly when I noticed the charge). (It appears that Palmer may be discontinuing its minibar service; during my last 2 stays in Feb and Mar 2007, the two rooms I was in no longer had minibars.) Rooms have typically been kept quite clean. Repairs often are not made promptly, and it can be quite some time before room-service items are removed from halls and floors, and trash is picked up. I've never used room-service delivery so can't comment on that. -- Location. Palmer House is located south of the Mag Mile area, so if you're envisioning Mag Mile/Rush Street-type activity at night, you won't find that around Palmer House. Dining in this part of the Loop is typically fairly poor in terms of variety and hours. Many places cater to the lunch crowd and close down at night. A plus is that the hotel is within walking distance of almost all downtown theaters (e.g. Goodman, Oriental) and extremely close to the Art Institute and Millennium Park. Note that usually the Wabash and State Street entrances close at night (hours of closing vary), and you must use the Monroe St. entrance at that time and show your key. I've walked around this area alone late at night many times and never felt unsafe (I'm female). I would avoid dark alleys and doorways, though. -- Public transportation. Extremely convenient to the Red Line el (a stop is located just outside the State Street entrance) and the Brown/Purple/Orange/Green Line els (a stop is located just south of the Wabash Street entrance). A few blocks to the nearest Blue Line el stop. One block from Michigan Avenue buses. --Parking. The Palmer House's "official" garage is the 55 E. Monroe complex, currently undergoing a major renovation and accessible for entry only from Monroe St (the Adams St exit is occasionally open, depending on construction activity). Both Monroe and Adams are one-way, so you need to plan your entry and exit to the garage well in advance. Cars tend to get very dirty in this garage at the moment because of all the construction dust being kicked up, so if that's important to you, park elsewhere. Rates are slightly discounted with a Palmer House stay, but are still expensive. -- Noise. It's an urban hotel; you will probably hear street noise no matter where in the hotel you are, although I consider myself quite noise-sensitive and I've never had trouble falling asleep because of noise here. Rooms facing Wabash are somewhat noisier because of the el directly underneath. In summary: I love the Palmer, despite its flaws -- it's like an old, familiar friend whose flaws you tolerate because of all the good things about her. By asking for what you want, you can avoid a number of the flaws and significantly improve your stay here. I hope others find the beauty in this old gem as well.

Reviews.Title: “Clean under Remodel,dont pay full rack rate but otherwise Perfect!”
Reviews.Author: Branuga
Reviews.Content: Stayed during Big Ten Torney! Staff 5 stars. Room 3.5 stars Location 4.5 Got lucky with Priceline bid of 120 per night. Located two short blocks from Magnificent Mile/Michagan St in between state and wabash .Has two entrances open during its remodel Monroe side and wabash.use theMonroe for the valet the 8 dollar difference a day for valet over self park is well worth the hassle. The bell men and dorr staff were great the first night we arrived in a rain storm(5/9) .The area is under some re construction work so the pierre scott building across the street is under reconstuction remodel and sits empty.The El is right outside on wabash and the red line is undergorund on state side entrance. Going inside youd expect the big lobby to be there. Errr sorry down the hall and up a very skinny escaltor that leads into the Grand lobby which is actually of to the side of this room you see in the pictures there is a bar / lounge that serves under this big area so you really cant take it all in and enjoy its art work and detail kind of a let down. They have a great front desk staff tried to upgrade or see what was available. offered upgrade which was basically the same room same size with just a conseirge pass to get free (non alcohol )drinks and snacks an a continental breakfast.(this is not recomended after seeing the list of what they offer with it.). In the lobby is a big costume jewley stand avoid this tourist trap at all cost with so much nicer shops all around why waste it in that over pirced costume jewelry. The room was very small as seen in the pics first one showing the bed / tv /desk area was taken from small lead in hall way by a small but very clean mable floored big bath tub bathroom. Careful the bottled water in the room is now 3.95 per bottle! 2.50 in the vending maching down the hall, there is a 7 eleven around the corner or a white hen one block down. One great plus about the room. The most comfortable bed I have slept on in years in a hotel .The Pillows were perfectly soft slept very well both nights there. The pool was small but nice an relaxing didnt use it to much maybe 3o minutes to much to do all around the area to sit an waste in pool. Local resturants they offer the big downtown (wabash) not so much ..Millers Pub is just one stop down! Great find the first night there their staff very friendly and the food was 4 star at 1 am ..recommend the feta and cheese and olives for the greek lovers and the baked chicken .for breakfast travel to the state street side and you can find BEEF n Brandy, Very cozt little diner that at night turns into a locals bar upstairs great breakfast biggest bang for the buck and is high quality with free wifi if you need to internet search for things to do in the area.cost 13 a day in the hotel. State street is lined with great shopping..macys nordstorm;s rack so on.. but go up michagn ave toward pierson and michagan to the water tower area, Some of the biggest retails are up in this area. Cab's are cheap so valet and let them do the driving , if you know where your going and sound smart the cabbies are ok. but you gotta pay attention for there are some bad ones there.You just say stop here pay them and get a new one. Careful panhandlers are every where not just here but all over downtown chicago not to aggressive just pesky and persistant ,but the area is very safe otherwise.

Reviews.Title: “Undergoing remodeling”
Reviews.Author: lscott
Reviews.Content: Multimillion$ "restoration" by new owner is underway. Restaurants closed except Downtowner. Bar and tables have taken over the lobby, carpeting removed in lobby to show classy marble floor. All shops in arcade closed, supposedly bringing in more upscale shops. Will stay open during constr. Our room on 19th floor was fine: large enough, well decorated, 2 small but compact and immaculate bathrooms. Coffee/tea in room, minibar closed off, $3.95 water but no tickets given us this time for free water. Hi speed internet in room, WIFI in public areas. We are HHonors members, pd $143 +taxes nonrefundable on Hilton website. $30 per day self parking. We stay here about once a year, go to play, eat at fav places, shop, Art museum. We missed lounging in lobby and people watching which was restricted somewhat by the table/chair arrangement and fear they will price us out of using this hotel by their uppity plans but the basic classy hotel..fancy ceiling, Tiffany fixtures, great location will still be there.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous place to stay”
Reviews.Author: kitt714
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel last spring break with our 3 kids (12, 11 and 4 at the time). It was a MARVELOUS experience! The staff was fantastic - housekeeping made up the beds with the kids stuffed animals and blankets (SOO cute) and made sure we had extra toiletries for all of us. Security took a special interest in us (toddler and autistic boy in our party) and really went out of their way to check on us! The location isn't so great for uptown but we cabbed everywhere. The restaurant attached to the hotel has okay food and not much seating which led to problems for us on Saturday night and we ended up at McDonald's around the corner but what could we expect for a weekend? Regarding the cabs - be careful which you choose! Coming out of the aquarium we chose a cab and got in. Immediately our cab was blocked by other cabs and those drivers got out and yelled at our driver and at US for "hopping the line!" We'd had no idea of this procedure and weren't about to get out of the cab. Our driver drove up and over a curb to get us away - it was frightening! Overall - really sumptuous place to stay :)

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay”
Reviews.Author: dkr1971
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Plamer house with my wife for one night on Feb 17th. After our stay I was a little surprised at some of the negative reviews. The lobby and common areas are beautiful. Yes, the rooms are a little small, but this hotel is in a great location in the middle of the city, so this is to be expected for a reasonably priced hotel. Drinks in the hotel bar are very expensive ($22 for two drinks), but this is not uncommon either, and the lobby/bar area is very comfortable and we enjoyed spending time there. We enjoyed our stay, and wil likely stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyable stay at the Palmer House”
Reviews.Author: trav05
Reviews.Content: My girlfriend and I stayed a weekend at the Palmer House and enjoyed the experience. I booked a room on the Hilton Website and took a non-refundable discount rate for an Executive floor room. The room was clean, good sized and and the beds were very comfortable. The hotel staff was very accomodating. The executive lounge had a continental breakfast that was just enough and an evening presentation of hors d'ouvres that was good as well. Executive lounge seemed very noisy when it filled up compared to other lounges I have used. We will return to the hotel in the future. PS if you like old architecture check out the lobby and inside the jewelry store that is located next to the entrance of the hotel, they don't build them like that anymore.

Reviews.Title: “Not the best!”
Reviews.Author: dasbar
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Palmer House Hilton in early Jan 2007 for 2 nights with my husband. We arrived at the hotel at the time advised to hotel by our travel agent to be greeted in a very unfriendly manner by the receptionist. We had pre-paid for rooms but there was a tense moment when apparently no free rooms could be found; this apparently was our fault as "all the other guests have checked in"???!! Anyway, we were allocated a room but it was not really of the standard I was anticipating - very small and musty smelling (probably not a room that's used often) with a view of the internal courtyard. I imagine we would have got a better room if booked direct with hotel. Facilities in the room are okay - nice toiletries, tea and coffee facilities (though these were not replaced during our stay) and minibar (water was $3 though I think! Usually free now in most good hotels...) Aside from teh receptionist, other staff encountered were very friendly and exceptionally helpful - as were the locals in general! The hotel has a reputation for its beautiful lobby and it certainly lives up to that particular expectation. It's also reputed to be the longest operating hotel in the US... it's starting to show its age in some aspects!! The location is good however (though not as lively as hotels located around Michigan Avenue); reasonably close to Monroe El stop (we came from airport by train as it's so cheap - only $2!) and within walking distance of the Art Institute and Millennium Park. Chicago is a fantastic city - I loved it and will definitely return sooner rather than later, but I'll be looking for a different hotel!

Reviews.Title: “A bit sad”
Reviews.Author: travlelf
Reviews.Content: The beautiful lobby ceiling is there as always, but , as they distinctly neglected to tell me when I booked, the hotel is currently undergoing renovation. Many on-site services and resturants are not currently operating. During low-traffic hours they are also refinishing the lobby floors. At the one bar/resturant available the food was excellent and the service staff were quick and capable. I wish I could say as much of the hotel concierge staff, who were abrupt, unhelpful and rude. Internet acess available in the lobby cost $4.95/15 min. + $1 per page to print, and when I had problems with the printer they were rude and dismissive. Similarly unhelpful on the question of where one might dine nearby (in view of the renovations and closed services) they handed me a list of 40 or so "nearby" establisments. Some of these were 4-6 city blocks away. The beds ,linens and bathroom facilities were superior, the housekeeping fine, heat and hot water quite adequate. Our room, however, was tiny and cramped with a "view" of a dark and gritty inner courtyard. The electronic door locks (ours and others I observed) were a real trick to open and I had to get one of the housekeeping staff to open ours for us the first time. (She said to me with seeming surprise "They gave you this little room?"- one has to wonder.) It was a great disappointment and I felt we didn't get good value for the price. Perhaps if I complained I could have gotten a switch or had them fix the door, etc., but I am not a complainer and don't feel I should have to complain to get a good product and good service. Beware---They have set up and promote a cheap and unpleasant costume jewelry vendor within the lobby entrance which is a tremendous rip-off. My young daughter noticed the $50 "gift certificate good for $50 off purchases of $60 or more in our registration packet and spent time looking for something to buy (throwing in her $20 spending money.) Everything stocked was either $49.95 or more than $80, except a bin of "sale" items for $10. We ended up buying her one of the $10 trinkets (the same stuff as the junk in the cases, it seemed to me-marked down from the outrageous ticket price) and trashed the faux "gift certificate." What a scam. It really made the place seem cheap and vulgar.

Reviews.Title: “Good and Bad”
Reviews.Author: robd
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Palmer House with our 2 kids for a long weekend. Immediately upon checking in, the front desk person gave us an "upgrade" to a room with two bathrooms. This was enormously helpful. The room itself was OK, the lighting was bad and the furnishings a bit dated and worn but in general it was satisfactory. But, the hotel in general seemed to lack the comforts and "extras" you might expect with a hotel of this class. The only real restaurant was very expensive and there were not many other attractions in the lobby area where there was construction going on. However, the gym was excellent, the pool a big plus for the kids and the staff for the most part was helpful. All in all, a mixed review.

Reviews.Title: “Horrible hotel! Don't stay here”
Reviews.Author: BusinessTraveler90
Reviews.Content: Pros ------- 1. Checkin anytime 2. Great gym 3. Overhead lighting in the room! 4. Free internet in Lobby area, supposedly Cons: EVERYTHING ELSE ----------------------------------- 1. Rude, incompetent front desk staff that lied to me about what my corporate rate covered. 2. Scratchy linens, uncomfortable bed 3. Ridiculously overpriced restaurant and in-room dining 4. Loud drilling and hammering that lasted all day and started, for the love of god, at 7 AM. Ridiculous! 5. Tiny, tiny, tiny bathroom. The sink area was so small that I had to put my makeup on my side table. 6. Tiny, tiny room that was very cramped. 7. In room internet is $12.95/day! I could go on and on about how awful this hotel really is, and I really wish I had not stayed here. I don't recommend it for business travelers at all. The hotel overall may have been a 4-star a long time ago but it's no more than a seriously overpriced 2-star, and my room was definitely a 2-star room.

Reviews.Title: “GreatHotel”
Reviews.Author: traveltheworld4fun
Reviews.Content: The Palmer is a older hotel with a historic feel. We booked early on the hotel website and got a great deal on a room with king size bed on their Executive Level with breakfast for two at a cost of $160 including tax. Note: Chicago Illinois hotel tax is expensive comming in around $20 for one night. Upon check in we were given two vouchers for bottled water in the room and were granted an extended check out time for no extra charge which was nice. Having a room on an executive floor has the added bonus of a private elevator which really cuts down on the wait time for an elevator. Our room was a little small but over all was clean and in great condition. The shower featured a double headed shower that was one of the best I have ever experinced. The only downer would be the breakfast included in our package. Though the resturant was decorated with some great Chicago memorbilia including a model "EL Train" which traveled through out the resturant, the food was sub-par for the price. In addition it was comical to watch the wait staff screw up the orders of ALL the tables around us. They seemed to be working really hard but werent managed well which resulted in the table next to us having 4 of their orders come out wrong. The sub quality of food combined with a poorly executed and trained resturant staff was a brief dissapointment for such a great hotel. I would recomend eating at one of the fantastic downtown resturants instead of eating in the hotel resturant. Overall the hotel is in a great location downtown Chicago and the lobby is fantastic. The room we had was great and in the center of Chicago shopping at Christmas.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel Experience!”
Reviews.Author: travelcatNJ
Reviews.Content: The reality is that this is an affordable hotel designed to make the middle class traveler feel a little bit special... The lobby is spectacular, the place is bustling with energy...yet my checkin took 5 minutes...there was no line, and we were even able to check in early. There are very FEW signs of wear...remember the hotel was built in the late 1800's... so give it a break. Our room was exceptionally clean, and I am a clean freak. The bed was so very comfortable, most mornings it was tempting to sleep the day away. The room was quiet...we stayed during the New Year weekend and never heard a peep from the hallway or any of the other rooms.The concierge was very helpful...they were always able to give us the correct information quickly. The rest of the hotel staff went out of their way to be friendly. The hotel is literally steps away from the train stop Adams/Wabash, and is a 10 minute walk to Grant Park and the Art Institute. One complaint I had is that the water pressure could have been better, and one word of advice...do not eat breakfast in the hotel restaurant...the prices are ridiculous, and you can get better food at the Corner Bakery Cafe for a much more reasonable price. Also, one more work of caution..beware of scam games on the trains...do not play any of them. I unfortunately witnessed a young woman lose $200 on the train from the airport to the hotel. Otherwise, do stay at this hotel, and enjoy all Chicago has to offer...you will not be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “Low class bunker masquerading as four-star hotel”
Reviews.Author: troubadourNYC
Reviews.Content: I made the awful mistake of trusting a third party's rating of this hotel as a four-star property. I stay in four-star hotels regularly, and this hotel is not one of them. Sure, the lobby is spectacular and well-maintained, but once you exit this sanctum, beware! First of all, there was a line to check into the hotel even though were only a few guests waiting to do so. Why? Because this is a massive property and they only had 2 people at the front desk. For a hotel this size, there should have been several clerks. Second, the king-size beds were all taken, so I was forced to take a room with a queen-size bed. Fine, but the bed was not queen-sized. I measured it, and it was 54", which makes it only a full-sized bed. When I told the front desk person this, she argued with me, until she finally agreed to give me another room. The room I was given did in fact have a queen-sized bed, but the overall room was still quite small. I had to turn sideways to walk past the bed, and the bathroom was microscopic.
